Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SusChEM: Developing Temporal Compartmentalization Tools in Yeast to Enhance the Bioproduction of Phytosterols

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant steroids are complex, naturally occurring molecules that have a wide variety of pharmaceutical and agricultural applications; however, they are usually found in quite small amounts in plants, and they are difficult to synthesize chemically. This research project investigates ways to engineer yeasts to produce these molecules. To accomplish this goal, it is necessary to introduce into the yeast the ability to perform the targeted degradation of specific proteins. The researchers on this project are employing advanced biochemical methods in order to realize this alteration in the yeast. This research project include specific activities for high school students and for undergraduate students from a local community college, which will help in developing a highly trained technical workforce for the biotechnology industry.

This research project provides a foundation for the development of programmable temporal regulation machinery for complex heterologous plant pathways in yeast. Such machinery employs yeast endogenous temporal compartmentalization strategies and an inducible protein degradation system associated with the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Introducing complex plant pathways into microbial hosts including yeast has been highly challenging, mainly due to 1) the high burden from the expression of large numbers of plant enzymes; and 2) the lack of efficient coordination among the many heterologous enzymatic steps. A plant biosynthetic platform is required to incorporate and validate the proposed temporal regulation strategy, as is a targeted protein degradation (TPD) approach. The biosynthetic pathway of the plant steroid hormone brassinosteroids (BRs) is being verified and established in yeast, which will enable the downstream establishment of the proposed temporal regulation strategies. In addition, the feasibility of introducing TPD in the proposed temporal regulation strategy is being evaluated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual:

1) Established a set of phytosterol (e.g. campesterol, 24-methylenecholesterol, fucosterol, and beta-sitosterol) producing yeast strains, which not only serves as the alternative sourcing for these phytosterols, but can also function as a platform for downstream pathway reconstitution and elucidation.

2) Elucidated the substrate specificity of SMT2 towards the putative substrates from episterol to 24-methylenecholesterol, and proposed the biosynthetic pathway of beta-sitosterol, which provides plant biologists insights into sterol composition engineering and regulation in plant.

3) Developed the engineering strategies for the construction of yeast strains producing exogenous sterols, such as campesterol and beta-sitosterols. 

4) Developed the fermentation strategies for optimal phytosterol production in yeast

5) We have obtained yeast mutant that retained campesterol production but with more robust growth. Demonstrate that the engineered phytosterol-producing yeast strains can adapt themselves as a more robust host under high growth stress introduced by the phytosterol bioproduction.

6) Obtained yeast strain mutant that rescued itself from the high growth burden introduced by campesterol biosynthetic pathway. We propose that through genome sequencing of this and campesterol-producing strains, we will be able to understand strategies yeast take to protect itself under high growth burden.

Education/Broader impacts:

1) Provided the research opportunity for one high school student and two undergraduate students. The high school student's work has been recently recognized by the gold medal in the regional competition of California High School Science Fair. One of the undergraduate students recently entered the biotechnology industry. 

2) In addition to serving as the platform for downstream pathway reconstruction, the phytosterol-producing yeast strains are also of commercial interests, and an invention provisional is being filed.
